Award.AwardTitle: Rebound vs Gateway Effects of Pro-Environmental Behavior

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many resources have been invested in programs to promote the voluntary adoption of pro-environmental behaviors (PEBs) through education, marketing, and economic incentives. Such investments, however, are threatened by the potential for rebound effects, by which the initial adoption of a PEB renders the adoption of subsequent PEBs less likely because the individual feels licensed to behave in environmentally counterproductive ways. On the other hand, an initial PEB may actually motivate the adoption of subsequent PEBs by reinforcing a pro-environmental identity, leading to gateway effects. The existence of gateway vs. rebound effects has profound implications for the effectiveness of environmental conservation programs and efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions through energy efficiency and conservation. Research to date has generated mixed results and has been limited by a reliance on correlational designs and by an incomplete investigation of the psychological and situational factors that facilitate and underlie these effects. The interdisciplinary research team for this project (cognitive and social psychology, decision theory, and law) draws on existing theories related to identity, emotions, moral self-regulation, and multiple modes of decision making to create and test a comprehensive theory of positive and negative pro-environmental behavior spillover. Does the adoption of a PEB affect the likelihood that an individual will adopt a subsequent PEB? What are the psychological processes by which rebound and gateway effects occur? Under what conditions are rebound and gateway effects most likely to occur? The research employs a mixed-methods approach that combines experiments and surveys conducted in both laboratory and field settings, using diverse populations. Research findings are disseminated through journal articles, workshops, and publications targeting policy makers and real-world decision makers.

The results from this research provides a foundation for evidence-based environmental policy that reduces the likelihood of counterproductive results or missed opportunities. By generating an understanding of the situations that give rise to rebound effects, the project's results provide insight to governments and private institutions about funding for initiatives that may be better spent on other policies and programs. By identifying the situations that give rise to gateway effects, the results will suggest when the promotion of one easy PEB can be expected to be a gateway to more demanding PEBs. The dissemination plan includes targeted publications and a dedicated workshop. Decision and policy makers in the government, non-profit and business sectors are also reached through a professionally designed communications guide that summarizes research findings in accessible language. Partnerships with corporate and community based organizations help transfer project findings into real-world demonstration projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many resources have been invested in efforts to promote pro-environmental behavior (PEB); for example, programs to promote recycling, energy conservation, or waste reduction. These are important strategies used by organizations and governments to save money, reduce environmental degradation, and preserve natural resources. However, these investments have the potential to be undermined by negative spillover effects, which occur when an initial adoption of a PEB reduces an individual’s motivation for subsequent, and potentially more impactful, pro-environmental action. Alternatively, a program that successfully promotes the adoption of an initial PEB may motivate or empower an individual to take subsequent action (positive spillover). The existence of positive or negative spillover effects has important implications for the design of environmental programs and policies. If negative spillover is common, it has the potential to undermine the benefits of environmental interventions. If positive spillover is common, we may be undervaluing such interventions and overlooking opportunities to promote more persistent or impactful pro-environmental behavior.

To date, there is relatively little work on behavioral spillover within the environmental context. The work that has been done is constrained by methodological limitations and has produced mixed results. This project involved a team of multi-disciplinary researcher from the fields of psychology, decision sciences, and law and policy. We used multiple methods, including surveys, experimental design, and meta-analysis to better understand the factors that cause positive or negative spillover, and to examine when and why spillover effects occur. We found that, overall, both positive and negative spillover effects are small. On average, the adoption of an initial PEB leads to a small increase in intentions to adopt a subsequent PEB, but a small decrease in actual adoption of a subsequent PEB. Positive spillover effects are most common between behaviors that are similar.

Our work also suggests that some types of pro-environmental interventions are more likely to result in spillover effects than others. Specifically, interventions that promote behavior change by targeting intrinsic motivation or personal concern for the environment increase the likelihood of positive spillover. Interventions that promote behavior change with the use of monetary incentives increase the probability of negative spillover. These findings suggest that there may be an opportunity to motivate persistent pro-environmental action by highlighting intrinsic reasons for environmental conservation rather than, or in addition to, focusing on extrinsic benefits.  

This work revealed several avenues for future research. Interventions that target behavior change by inducing feeling of guilts about environmental degradation—a commonly utilized strategy—have produced mixed results and should be explored in future research. Furthermore, interventions that utilize social norms to change behavior are increasingly common; yet, few studies have examined spillover effects that result from this class of interventions. More research is also needed to examine spillover effects between actual behaviors in natural settings to complement and extend the preponderance of work that has been done in controlled laboratory environments.

This funding supported the training and professional development of six graduate and three undergraduate students, three postdoctoral fellows, and two early career faculty investigators. This project also brought together a diverse community of researchers, decision makers, and practitioners from across the public and private sectors to discuss the application of key findings and to develop recommendations for future research.
